description.narrative: C4D: The capacity of Government, NGOs, CBOs, and Traditional/Religious leaders is built to mobilise and promote behaviour and social change through the adoption of key family practices., which contributes to Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 7: Social Protection and Communication for Development (C4D): Vulnerable and marginalized families with children across Ghana access and utilize improved social services and are empowered to adopt key family practices.

participating-org.narrative: MINISTRY OF LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND RURAL DEVELOPMENT GAR

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: C4D: The capacity of Government, NGOs, CBOs, and Traditional/Religious leaders is built to mobilise and promote behaviour andsocial change through the adoption of key family practices.

description.narrative: UNICEF supported training of over 11,000 government and civil society agents in interpersonal communication and social mobilization. As a result, 1.1 million people in five regions directly reached and 12 million indirectly reached by mass media. Ghana's first Knowledge Seminar on behavior change held, to advocate for C4D mainstreaming. | Status:Met | As-of Date:21/12/2017

title.narrative: Number of communities / households reached in the selected districts through mobilisation sessions conducted by the government, civil society, religious /traditional leaders and the media to promote key family practices in the 5 selected regions

Number of partners (government, civil society, religious and traditional leaders and the media) at national, regional and district level trained to implement the multisectoral C4D strategy in the 5 selected regions
